aGUWAx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
Associated with medium to large streams.  Completely aquatic.

Even though this species is entirely aquatic, the original model had map units selected but a 0m exterior flowing water buffer. The 0m buffer essentially eliminates all map unit selections. In order to include areas such as stream banks, I changed the exterior buffer to 30m. I also made a similar change to the Black Warrior Waterdog model. MJR 15 May 2009.

aGUWAx-y5.memHandModelNotes:
Associated with medium to large streams.  Completely aquatic.

Even though this species is entirely aquatic, the original model had map units selected but a 0m exterior flowing water buffer. The 0m buffer essentially eliminates all map unit selections. In order to include areas such as stream banks, I changed the exterior buffer to 30m. I also made a similar change to the Black Warrior Waterdog model. MJR 15 May 2009.

references: Guyer, C. 2005. Necturus beyeri (Viosca 1937), Gulf Coast Waterdog. In Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA. p.867-868.
Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
IUCN. 2014. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1. http://www.iucnredlist.org. Downloaded March 2016.
Jensen, J. B., C. D. Camp, W. Gibbons, and M. J. Elliot, editors. 2008. Amphibians and reptiles of Georgia. University of Georgia Press, Athens. 575 pp.
habitat_description: Found in unpolluted, sandy bottom spring-fed streams (Conant and Collins 1998). This species will not be found in turbid, sluggish waters charcteristic of bayous, rivers, and lakes typical of the Lower Mississippi drainage system (Guyer 2005). They are most common in medium to large streams.  Logjams and leaf beds are important habitats for adults (Petranka 1998).
